body: A 'Nutcracker,' Short and Sweet If you take young children to a full-length production of ''The Nutcracker,'' they may depart for their own dream kingdom long before the heroine finds herself in the Land of Sweets. There should be no nodding off, however, at the version to be staged by the New York Theater Ballet: the performance is not only
title: FAMILY FARE

body: IT'S a big, unwieldy city, but three recent books serve it up in more manageable pieces. David Masello, New York correspondent for Art & Antiques magazine, takes the reader on a virtual walk that covers 50 notable public artworks. Carol J. Binkowski, staff organist at the Church Center for the United Nations, traces the history of music in the city
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: N.Y. BOOKSHELF; Serving Up the Vast City In Bite-Size Pieces

body: The two on-line stock promoters found shot to death on Tuesday in a mansion in Colts Neck, N.J., had been informers in investigations of securities fraud, regulatory and law enforcement officials said yesterday. But investigators said they were uncertain whether the information the men provided was sufficiently damaging to provoke such an attack.
title: Stock Promoters Were Informers, Said to Aid Inquiries in Fraud

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. Costumes, set pieces, film equipment and other items relating to film, television and video are on permanent display. Exhibitions include ''Behind the Screen,'' a permanent display with more than a thousand artifacts that
title: SPARE TIMES

body: FIRST Ambrose Afondeur took scuba diving lessons in the Y.M.C.A. pool on the Upper West Side. Then he did what most other aspiring divers who live in New York City do. For the four open-water dives required for his certification, he jetted off to a warmer clime: Maui, Hawaii. Later, it was the coral reefs off the Cayman Islands in the Caribbean
title: The Urban Deep

body: A state appeals court has ruled that a group of Brooklyn residents can challenge city plans that would transform Dreier-Offerman Park, near Coney Island. Named after a German-American home for unwed mothers that once owned part of the land, the park is known mostly as a wasteland of weeds, old tires and abandoned appliances. But its ball fields are
title: Appeals Court Says Residents Can Challenge Plans for Park

body: A $66-million expansion and renovation of the Menorah Home and Hospital for the Aged and Infirm has begun along Oriental Boulevard in the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn. Once the project is completed in February 2001, the institution's outdated 273-bed Bushwick campus will be shut down. The waterfront project, financed by bonds issued by the
title: POSTINGS: For the Menorah Home and Hospital; A $66-Million Expansion and Renovation

body: AN arc of gray seagulls banked against a cold gust of wind and wheeled high above Brighton Beach toward the Atlantic Ocean. Sofia Garber followed the birds with her big blue eyes and pulled the fur collar of her coat to her cheeks. Standing on an expanse of boardwalk between a line of apartment buildings and the sand, Ms. Garber, 51, reflected on
title: From Brighton Beach to America; The Wave of Immigrants Began 25 Years Ago. Soon Russian Filled the Streets. Now, the Tide Is Ebbing.

body: TROSTEN-Anne Belkin, who died February 27, 1999, in Chatham, NY, was born in Torrington, CT, in 1901. She graduated in 1922 from the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital School of Nursing. Mrs. Trosten is the widow of the late David Trosten of Brooklyn, NY. She is survived by her sons, William Trosten of Manhattan and Chatham, NY, and Leonard Trosten of
title: Paid Notice: Deaths TROSTEN, ANNE BELKIN

body: New York City will hold a special election tomorrow to replace three City Council members who have moved on to other posts. The winners must all stand for re-election this fall. If they keep their seats, they have a chance to develop substantial influence in a body where most incumbents must leave office in 2001, when term limits kick in. District
title: City Council Endorsements

body: GOLDSTEIN-Leon M. The City College of New York mourns the passing of President Leon M. Goldstein of Kingsborough Community College, who was also a distinguished alumnus of CCNY. Under his leadership, Kingsborough became one of the nation's most innovative and successful community colleges. President Goldstein also rendered valuable service to CUNY
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GOLDSTEIN, LEON M.

body: Work began last month on transforming an empty lot along Emmons Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, into a 104-unit apartment building that will provide elderly tenants with meals, services and personal care. When completed in 12 months, the $22 million project, called Sunrise on the Bay, will have studio to two-bedroom apartments with 300 to 700
title: Residential Real Estate; Brooklyn Project Aims At People 75 and Older

body: A Lower East Side landlord pleaded guilty yesterday to trying to kill two of his tenants who had complained about conditions in his building and planning to set fire to one of their apartments. The landlord, Alvin Weiss, who prosecutors said waged a campaign of terror against the two tenants, will be sentenced to 7 to 14 years in prison on Feb. 18,
title: Landlord Admits He Is Guilty Of Trying to Kill Two Tenants
